 A:  Reducing the need for blood transfusion
 B:  Increasing the risk of pulmonary edema
 C:  Complicating the management of head injury
 D:  Reducing the volume of fluid required for resuscitation
 E:  Increasing the volume of blood loss to produce maternal hypotension
378.answer_content: Increasing the volume of blood loss to produce maternal hypotension

379.query:
A 35-year-old lady presented with a breast lump, 2 cm X 2 cm, next to the nipple. There were three mobile axillary nodes. There was no skin involvement and not fixed to the pectoral muscle. Trucut biopsy of the lump showed duct carcinoma. Sentinel node biopsy was negative. There was no evidence of distant metastases. Given this information ONLY, the best option of her management is:
 A:  Do simple mastectomy, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy.
 B:  Do simple mastectomy, axillary lymph node dissection, chemotherapy and radiotherapy
 C:  Do modified radical mastectomy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, tamoxifen, and Herceptin
 D:  Do modified radical mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy
 E:  Do conservation breast surgery, axillary lymph node biopsy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy
379.answer_content: Do conservation breast surgery, axillary lymph node biopsy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy

380.query:
Which of the following necessitates a definitive airway following trauma
 A:  Facial lacerations
 B:  Repeated vomiting
 C:  Severe maxillofacial fractures
 D:  Sternal fracture
 E:  GCS of 12

Which of the following parameters should NOT be used routinely to monitor patients in the early stages of shock?

 B:  Blood pressure recordings
 C:  Urine output through a foleys catheter
 D:  Mixed venous oxygen saturation
 E:  All may be used

382.query:

 A:  Enzyme supplementation
 B:  Fluid resuscitation
 C:  Empiric antibiotics
 D:  Full oral diet
 E:  Enrollment in alcohol abstinence counseling

 A:  Superficial burn
 B:  Partial thickness superficial
 C:  Deep partial thickness burn
 D:  Full thickness burn
 E:  4th degree burn

 A:  An open pneumothorax
 B:  A tension pneumothorax

 A:  A viral infection.

 C:  Obstruction of the appendiceal lumen.
 D:  A primary clostridial infection.
 E:  Appendiceal cancer

387.query:
An 18-year old girl is brought to the emergency department with worsening severe lower abdominal pain that started 6 hours ago. Her abdomen is tender particularly in the lower quadrants and there is guarding. She is tachycardic but her blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg. Which one of the following is the most important diagnosis that you should rule out/confirm in this patient?
 A:  Acute appendicitis
 B:  Pelvic inflammatory disease
 C:  Acute intestinal obstruction
 D:  Ectopic pregnancy
 E:  Intestinal obstruction

388.query:
A 47 year old lady presents to the emergency department with complaints of epigastric pain. She also feels nauseated and has vomited several times over the past 24 hours. The pain did not respond to over the counter antacids which she tried. On examination she was an obese lady. Her liver enzymes were marginally elevated.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient
 A:  Acute appendicitis
 B:  Acute cholecystitis
 C:  Acute ovarian torsion
 D:  Diverticulitis
 E:  n/a

389.query:
A 47 year old lady presents to the emergency department with complaints of epigastric pain. She also feels nauseated and has vomited several times over the past 24 hours. The pain did not respond to over the counter antacids which she tried. On examination she was an obese lady. Her liver enzymes were marginally elevated.
Which ONE of the following is the most appropriate next investigation for this patient?
 A:  Erect abdominal X-ray
 B:  Endoscopy
 C:  Ultrasound scan of the abdomen
 D:  H1 breath test for Helicobacter Pylori
 E:  n/a

 A:  Broad spectrum antibiotics alone
 B:  Urgent surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics
 C:  Urgent surgical debridement and immediate flap
 D:  Palliative care
 E:  Oral analgesics
390.answer_content: Urgent surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics

 A:  Benign prostatic hyperplasia
 B:  Diabetes mellitus
 C:  Hyperthyroidism
 D:  Hypertension
 E:  None of the above

392.query:
which of the following clinical signs would you expect to find in a patient with cardiac tamponade?
 A:  Muffled heart sounds
 B:  Hypotension
 C:  Distended neck veins
 D:  All of the above
 E:  None of these

393.query:
A 79-year-old man has had abdominal pain for 4 days. An operation is performed, and a gangrenous appendix is removed. Why does acute appendicitis in elderly patients and in children have a worse prognosis?
 A:  The appendix is retrocecal.
 B:  There may be a delay in establishing the right diagnosis in these age groups.
 C:  The appendix is in the pelvic position.
 D:  The omentum and peritoneal cavity appear to be less efficient in localizing the disease in these age groups.
 E:  B and D.

394.query:
A 24-year old male patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain for 1 day. He reports that the pain is progressively worsening and located mainly in the right lower quadrant and does not radiate. He has had 2 episodes of vomiting and reports loss of appetite since the pain began. On examination he is sick-looking. His heart rate is 124/min and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. His temperature is 37.8. there is right iliac fossa tenderness but no rebound tenderness. The patient has an elevated C-reactive protein of 201 (normal 0-5). Full hemogram shows Hemoglobin of 14, white cell count of 22 (normal 4-11) with neutrophils of 95%
The ALVARADO score in this patient is
 A:  8
 B:  7
 C:  6
 D:  3
 E:  n/a

395.query:
A 20-year old female presents with complaints of general abdominal pain. she reports multiple episodes of diarrhea and vomiting. On examination she is afebrile but appears moderately dehydrated. Her abdomen is moderately tender in the peri-umbilical and epigastric regions. There is no guarding or rebound tenderness. Her white cell count is normal. Which of the following statements correctly describes the next course of management?
 A:  A diagnosis of acute abdomen should be made and laparotomy performed immediately
 B:  An abdominal CT scan is required to determine the pathology
 C:  Insert a nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach
 D:  Non surgical causes of acute abdomen should be considered
 E:  Do an urgent MRI of the abdomen
395.answer_content: Non surgical causes of acute abdomen should be considered

396.query:
Which of the following tests should be reviewed to work up a patient for pancreatitis?
 A:  Lipase, amylase, triglycerides
 B:  Amylase, serum calcium, hemoglobin
 C:  Triglycerides, hemoglobin, serum glucose
 D:  Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), lipase, serum magnesium
 E:  n/a

397.query:
You are asked to see a 35-year old female who sustained a head injury during a road traffic accident. The patient was stable upon arrival to the emergency department but over the last hour his GCS has fallen from 15/15 to 13/15 and is now is drowsy and complaining of a headache. What is the most appropriate next step to take in the patient’s management?
 A:  Repeat the GCS score in another 3 hours
 B:  Speak with the neurosurgeon on call with a view of taking the patient to theatre
 C:  Prescribe adequate analgesia
 D:  Request an urgent CT scan of the head
 E:  Prescribe an intravenous infusion of mannitol
397.answer_content: Request an urgent CT scan of the head

398.query:
You see a 48-year old in the surgical ward who is due for an exploratory laparotomy. The anaesthetist tells you that a high dependency unit (HDU) bed has been booked for the patient owing to his comorbidities and will therefore require close monitoring after surgery. The anesthetist tells you that the patient falls under ASA 3. From the list below, choose the definition that best describes an ASA grading of 3.
 A:  A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without an operation
 B:  A patient with mild systemic disease
 C:  A normal healthy patient
 D:  A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life
 E:  A patient with severe systemic disease
398.answer_content: A patient with severe systemic disease

399.query:
which of the following is NOT a sign associated with acute appendicitis
 A:  Psoa’s sign
 B:  Rovsing’s sign
 C:  Murphy’s sign
 D:  Obturator sign
 E:  All of the above

400.query:
A 85-year old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting and absolute constipation. Examination reveals a distended tympanic abdomen. Plain abdominal radiograph shows a grossly dilated large bowel arising from the left lower quadrant. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is
 A:  Sigmoid volvulus
 B:  Acute pancreatitis
 C:  Paralytic ileus
 D:  Gastric cancer
 E:  Perforated duodenal ulcer

401.query:
During a ward round, you are asked by your senior registrar to name the most common causative factor that is responsible for the development of acute pancreatitis. Which option from the list below would you choose as your answer?
 A:  Gallstones
 B:  Ethanol
 C:  Steroids
 D:  Drugs
 E:  Trauma

402.query:
which of the following scenarios best describes parietal type of abdominal pain?
 A:  51-year old with poorly localized abdominal pain
 B:  85-year old female with acute bowel ischemia
 C:  29-year old female with localized right lower quadrant pain
 D:  31-year old male with scrotal pain following trauma
 E:  None of the above
402.answer_content: 29-year old female with localized right lower quadrant pain

403.query:
which of the following about testicular torsion is TRUE
 A:  Urine analysis will reveal pyuria and lead to diagnosis
 B:  C-reactive protein levels are always elevated
 C:  Laboratory tests are not sensitive in diagnosis
 D:  White blood cells are always elevated
 E:  Abdominal CT scan is a necessary investigation
403.answer_content: Laboratory tests are not sensitive in diagnosis

404.query:
A 3-year-old male weighing 16 kg (35.3 pounds) presents with second and third-degree burns of his anterior trunk, upper back, and right arm, after pulling a large pot of boiling water off the stove onto himself. This is a 23% total body surface area burn. Fluid resuscitation is started based on the Parkland formula. When reassessing this patient 3 hours after starting fluid resuscitation, what would be an appropriate urine output?
 A:  0.25 mL/kg/hour
 B:  2.0 mL/kg/hour
 C:  1.0 ml/kg/hour
 D:  3.5 ml/kg/hour
 E:  4.0 ml/kg/hour

405.query:
45-year-old patient is involved in a road traffic accident and is noted to have bruising all over the chest and he complains of severe chest pain. On examination he has a shallow tachypnoea with indrawing of the chest wall on inspiration. The trachea is central. Oxygen saturation is 86 per cent on air, pulse 110/min, BP 100/65 mmHg. The likely injury this patient has sustained is
 A:  Cardiac tamponade
 B:  Tension pneumothorax
 C:  Flail chest
 D:  Spinal injury
 E:  None of the above

406.query:

 A:  Retroileal
 B:  Subileal
 C:  Paracecal
 D:  Retrocecal
 E:  Pelvic

407.query:

 B:  Abdominal pain is usually localized in the left upper quadrant
 C:  Nausea and vomiting are often present
 D:  Epigastric tenderness can be observed on examination
 E:  None of the above
407.answer_content: Abdominal pain is usually localized in the left upper quadrant

408.query:
Which clinical feature is NOT likely to occur with a tension pneumothorax?
 A:  Hypertension
 B:  Unilateral decrease in breath sounds
 C:  Tachycardia
 D:  Tracheal shift
 E:  All of the above

409.query:
What is the total body surface area involved in a burn in an adult to the anterior chest and abdomen?
 A:  9 percent
 B:  18 percent
 C:  27percent
 D:  36 percent
 E:  45 percent

410.query:

 A:  Decreased cerebral perfusion
 B:  Decreased cerebral oxygenation
 C:  Direct cerebral injury
 D:  All of the above
 E:  A and B

411.query:
Which of the following conditions can severely impair the ability of a patient to ventilate following trauma?
 A:  Tension pneumothorax
 B:  Flail chest with pulmonary contusion
 C:  Massive hemothorax
 D:  Open pneumothorax
 E:  All of the above

412.query:
What metabolic state can result from continued hemorrhage or decreased perfusion?
 A:  Metabolic alkalosis
 B:  Respiratory acidosis
 C:  Mixed respiratory and metabolic alkalosis
 D:  Metabolic acidosis
 E:  None of the above

413.query:
Which choice correctly matches percent body volume loss by hemorrhage to signs and symptoms?
 A:  Ten percent, mild tachycardias, normal capillary refill, and clear sensorium
 B:  Fifteen percent, tachycardia, normotensive with widened pulse pressure, and decreased level of consciousness
 C:  Twenty percent, tachycardia without palpable pulses and clear sensorium 
 D:  Thirty percent, tachycardia, normotensive, and clear sensorium
 E:  None of the above are correct
413.answer_content: Ten percent, mild tachycardias, normal capillary refill, and clear sensorium

414.query:
A 22-yearold man is brought to the hospital after crashing his motorcycle into a telephone pole. He is unconscious and in profound shock. He has no open wounds or obvious fractures. The cause of his shock is MOST LIKELY caused by:
 A:  A subdural hematoma.
 B:  An epidural hematoma.
 C:  A transected lumbar spinal cord.

 E:  Hemorrhage into the chest or abdomen
414.answer_content: Hemorrhage into the chest or abdomen

415.query:
A general surgeon contacts you regarding preoperative clearance for an otherwise healthy 42-year-old scheduled for an appendectomy. The patient has no history of excessive bleeding, no family history of bleeding disorders, and is on no medications. He inquires about the need for coagulation studies, which have not been performed. Which of the following is a correct response to this inquiry?

Examination reveals normal facial strength; quadriparesis with 3/5 strength in proximal upper and lower extremities and 0/5 strength in bilateral ankle dorsiflexion, plantarflexion, inversion and eversion; intact sensory function; and generalized areflexia. Nerve conduction studies demonstrate reduced distal motor amplitudes, but no evidence of conduction block. Sensory conduction studies are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 A:  Aute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP)
 B:  Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
 C:  Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)
 D:  Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP)

 B:  Cervical myelopathy
 C:  Myasthenia gravis
 D:  Mononeuropathy multiplex
 E:  Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy

 E:  Respiratory alkalosis by arterial blood gases
1200.answer_content: Acellular spinal fluid with high protein

Which of the following best summarizes the role of interferon β for this disease?

 C:  It improves survival
 D:  It improves patients’ symptoms and has no significant side effects

 B:  Causes glander-like disease of animals and man
 C:  Causes malignant pustule
 D:  Causes malignant otitis
 E:  Causes enteritis necroticans

2989.query:
In the laboratory diagnosis of anaerobic infections,
 A:  It is easy to differentiate anaerobes from contaminants
 B:  Antibiotic susceptibility test of anaerobes is routinely indicated
 C:  Slow growth of anaerobes is due to inefficient means of energy generation
 D:  Samples from site of anaerobic infection can be transported in routine transport medium 	such as Stuart or Aimes
 E:  None of the above is correct
2989.answer_content: Slow growth of anaerobes is due to inefficient means of energy generation

2990.query:
The following are strict anaerobes
 A:  Fusobacterium nucleatum
 B:  Pseudomonas aeruginosa
 C:  Bacteroides thetaiotamicron
 D:  Gardnerella vaginalis
 E:  Moraxella catarrhalis

2991.query:
The following are common characteristics of anaerobic infection?
 A:  are usually monomicrobial in nature
 B:  are usually polymicrobial in nature
 C:  are uncommon in clinical practice
 D:  are associated with crepitus on palpation
 E:  are associated with all of the above

2992.query:
With respect to the pathogenesis of Haemophilus influenzae infections;
 A:  endogenous infections are caused by capsulate strains
 B:  endogenous infections are caused by non-capsulate strains
 C:  exogenous infections are caused by non-capsulate strains
 D:  a & b are correct
 E:  only b is correct
2992.answer_content: endogenous infections are caused by non-capsulate strains

2993.query:
The following Haemophilus species require both X and V factors for growth;
 A:  Haemophilus ducreyi
 B:  Haemophilus aegyptius
 C:  Haemophilus aphrophilus
 D:  Haemophilus haemoglobinophilus
 E:  Haemophilus haemolyticus

2994.query:
Concerning meningococcal septicaemia;
 A:  occurs without a prior respiratory tract infection
 B:  common in age group 3 months to 3 years
 C:  Waterhouse-Frederickson syndrome is pathognomonic
 D:  associated with deficiency of complement system
 E:  all of the above are true
2994.answer_content: common in age group 3 months to 3 years

2995.query:
The following sugar reactions are useful in identifying Neisseria species from laboratory cultures;
 A:  Neisseria gonorrheae oxidizes glucose and maltose
 B:  Neisseria meningitidis oxidizes only glucose
 C:  Neisseria lactamica oxidizes glucose, maltose and lactose
 D:  a & b are correct
 E:  a & c are correct
2995.answer_content: Neisseria lactamica oxidizes glucose, maltose and lactose

2996.query:
Virulent factors of Neisseria gonorrheae include;
 A:  lipo-oligosaccharide
 B:  M protein
 C:  polypeptide capsule
 D:  pili
 E:  none of the above

2997.query:
The following Prion diseases are infectious in nature
 A:  Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker Syndrome (GSS)
 B:  Scrapie
 C:  Fatal Familiar Insomnia
 D:  Feline Spongiform Encephalopathies
 E:  None of the above

2998.query:
Concerning pathogenic factors of autoimmune diseases, the following are correctly matched;
 A:  Polio virus ………………………………………..IDDM
 B:  Adenovirus ……………………………………. Celiac disease
 C:  Klebsiella pneumoniae ………………………. Rheumatoid arthritis
 D:  Group A streptococci ……………………….. Myasthenia Gravis
 E:  Epstein Barr virus …………………………….. Ankylosing spondylitis

2999.query:
Concerning clinical laboratory safety and infection control;
 A:  Biosafety level 1 (BSL-1) offers basic protection against Ebola virus
 B:  Only standard precautions are necessary in the laboratory
 C:  Running water is a necessity for infection prevention
 D:  Biosafety cabinets are required by all clinical laboratories
 E:  All of the above
2999.answer_content: Running water is a necessity for infection prevention

3000.query:
Standard precautions for infection control include;
 A:  Hand hygiene
 B:  Recapping of used needles
 C:  Wearing of ward coats
 D:  Proper disposal of healthcare wastes
 E:  All of the above

3001.query:
The objectives of infection control program in the hospital include;
 A:  To eradicate all hospital acquired infections
 B:  To isolate all patients with hospital acquired infections
 C:  To develop safe practice and good environment for the hospital population
 D:  All of the above
 E:  None of the above
3001.answer_content: To develop safe practice and good environment for the hospital population

3002.query:
The following statements correctly describe hospital acquired infections;
 A:  Infections in hospitalized patients
 B:  Infections incubating at the time of hospital admission
 C:  Infections occurring within 48 hours of hospital admission
 D:  Infections occurring after 48 hours of hospital admission
 E:  All of the above
3002.answer_content: Infections occurring after 48 hours of hospital admission

3003.query:
Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include;
 A:  Janeway lesions
 B:  osteodystrophy
 C:  pettechiae haemorrhages
 D:  rose spot
 E:  spider naevi

3004.query:
Endocarditis in Intravenous Drug Users (IVDU);
 A:  is frequently a left sided infection
 B:  Staphylococcus aureus is infrequently involved
 C:  Serratia marcescens frequently cause left sided infection with high mortality
 D:  associated with embolic phenomena to the brain
 E:  none of the above
3004.answer_content: Serratia marcescens frequently cause left sided infection with high mortality

3005.query:
The following microbial agents frequently cause native valve endocarditis (NVE)
 A:  Coagulase negative staphylococci
 B:  Granulicatella species
 C:  Pseudomonas aeruginosa
 D:  HACEK bacteria
 E:  all of the above

3006.query:
Which of the following statements about filariasis is True?
 A:  Mature worms can be seen in nocturnal peripheral blood smear
 B:  Blood tests often reveal an elevated lymphocyte count
 C:  Medical treatment with diethylcarbamazepine is effective even when huge elephantiasis occurs
 D:  Hydroceles are treated in the usual way but excess skin may need trimming
 E:  Elephantiasis can be easily treated with operations to reduce the size of the limb
3006.answer_content: Hydroceles are treated in the usual way but excess skin may need trimming

3007.query:
Which of the following can NOT be found in roundworm infestation?
 A:  High eosinophil count
 B:  Larvae in sputum or bronchoscopic lavage
 C:  Fluffy exudates on chest X-rays
 D:  Barium meal may show the worm lying freely in the lumen
 E:  Chacot-Leyden crystals in stool

3008.query:
Which of the following are caused by Ascaris lumbricoides (Ascariasis)?
 A:  Pulmonary symptoms primarily as an adult worm
 B:  Intestinal symptoms as a larva
 C:  Intestinal symptoms as an adult worm
 D:  Biliary disease as a larva
 E:  Muscular symptoms as a larva
3008.answer_content: Intestinal symptoms as an adult worm

3009.query:
Which of the following is True concerning Hookworm infestation?
 A:  The infective larvae (third stage larvae) survive in the soil for months
 B:  It commonly causes diarrhea in non-immunes
 C:  The worm  may block the pancreatic duct causing pancreatitis
 D:  It  is usually diagnosed by microscopy of adhesive tape prints taken from the perianal area
 E:  The eggs can be readily distinguished microscopically from those of Strongyloides sp.
3009.answer_content: The infective larvae (third stage larvae) survive in the soil for months

3010.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning Hydatid disease?
 A:  It is usually accompanied by eosinophilia
 B:  Cysts found on ultrasound scan may be confused with liver abscesses, carcinomatous metastases, hepatoma or polycystic disease
 C:  It is best diagnosed by microscopy of fluid obtained from ultrasound guided aspiration of the suspected cyst
 D:  It is treated with crystalline penicillin
 E:  Surgical removal of cysts should not be attempted
3010.answer_content: Cysts found on ultrasound scan may be confused with liver abscesses, carcinomatous metastases, hepatoma or polycystic disease

3011.query:
The treatment for an amoebic abscess includes the following  EXCEPT
 A:  Medical treatment with Metronidazole or Tinidazole
 B:  Medical treatment with Diloxanide furoate is not sufficient
 C:  Aspiration may be carried out for abscesses which present with features of imminent rupture
 D:  Urgent laparotomy upon diagnosis
 E:  Surgical treatment for amoebiasis is indicated for a ruptured liver abscess

3012.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning Amoebic liver abscess?
 A:  It occurs most commonly in men aged 60 years and above
 B:  It usually affects the right lobe of the liver
 C:  It is associated with eosinophilia
 D:  It should be aspirated routinely
 E:  It should be treated by Diloxanide furoate alone
3012.answer_content: It usually affects the right lobe of the liver

3013.query:
Which of the following lesions does NOT produce suppurative lymphadenopathy?
 A:  Cat scratch fever
 B:  Lymphogranuloma venereum
 C:  Plague
 D:  Sarcoidosis
 E:  Tuberculosis

3014.query:
The following are true of Genital ulcers EXCEPT
 A:  They are found in gonorrhea
 B:  They may be due to herpes simplex virus
 C:  They are associated with an increased incidence of HIV
 D:  If the ulcers are painful and associated with lymphadenopathy, are likely to be due to chancroid
 E:  If the ulcers are well-defined and beefy red, are likely to be due to granuloma inguinale

3015.query:
Which of the following statements about leprosy (Hansen’s disease) is NOT True?
 A:  Patients may present with asymmetrical, well-defined, anesthetic, hypopigmented or erythematous macules with elevated edges and a dry rough surface
 B:  There are often nodular lesions on the patient’s face in the acute phase of the lepromatous variety.
 C:  Patients have neural involvement characterized by thickening of nerves, which are tender
 D:  The condition is diagnosed by demonstrating bacilli in urine
 E:  The patient is treated by a multidisciplinary team of infection disease specialist and  surgeons
3015.answer_content: The condition is diagnosed by demonstrating bacilli in urine

3016.query:
Which of the following statements is NOT True in the treatment for typhoid perforation?
 A:  Perforation occurring in the first week of typhoid fever has a better prognosis as the patient’s nutritional and immunological status is better
 B:  Treatment involves vigorous resuscitation with intravenous  fluids and antibiotics in an intensive care unit
 C:  Chloramphenicol is the drug of choice
 D:  Several surgical options can be carried out, depending on the condition of the patient, the site and number of perforations and the amount of peritoneal soiling
 E:  The skin and subcutaneous tissue are often kept open for delayed closure, as wound infection inevitably happens, leading to wound dehiscence
3016.answer_content: Chloramphenicol is the drug of choice

3017.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning Tuberculoid leprosy?
 A:  Skin lesions usually have a well-demarcated, raised edge
 B:  Hair growth is normal in affected skin lesions
 C:  Peripheral nerves are involved symmetrically
 D:  The lepromin test is negative
 E:  Smear negative cases can be treated with steroids alone
3017.answer_content: Skin lesions usually have a well-demarcated, raised edge

3018.query:
Surgery for ileal and ileocecal tuberculosis may involve
 A:  Limited ileocolic resection
 B:  Right hemicolectomy
 C:  Ileo-transverse anastomosis
 D:  Stricturoplasty
 E:  All of the above

3019.query:
Which of the following types of lesion may be caused by intestinal infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
 A:  Transverse ulcers with undermined edges in the ileum
 B:  Longitudinal ulcers on the antimesenteric border of the terminal ileum
 C:  Tubercles on the mucosal aspect of the intestine
 D:  Apple-core lesions of the colon
 E:  Transmural inflammation with a propensity for fistula formation
3019.answer_content: Transverse ulcers with undermined edges in the ileum

3020.query:
Which of these characteristically describes a Buruli ulcer?
 A:  It is caused by Fusobacterium
 B:  It is secondarily infected
 C:  It is responsive to Penicillin
 D:  Ulcer is described as painful
 E:  The edges are described as undermined
3020.answer_content: The edges are described as undermined

3021.query:
The most urgent measure in the management of a  severely injured patient in the reception room is
 A:  Control of active bleeding
 B:  Taking blood sample for grouping and cross matching
 C:  Establishing an intravenous line
 D:  Securing clear and adequate pulmonary ventilation
 E:  Providing tetanus prophylaxis
3021.answer_content: Securing clear and adequate pulmonary ventilation

3022.query:
Following splenectomy for trauma
 A:  Infection with Plasmodium falciparum and Hemophilus influenzae are usually uncommon
 B:  Heinz bodies are characteristically seen on the blood film
 C:  Thrombocytopenia is typical
 D:  Pneumococcal vaccine should be given
 E:  Prophylactic penicillin should be taken for six weeks

3023.query:
Which of the following statements is True about Tropical splenomegaly syndrome?
 A:  There is Plasmodium falciparum parasitemia
 B:  There is lymphocytic infiltration of hepatic sinusoids
 C:  There is very low or absent malarial antibody titers
 D:  There is reduced serum IgM
 E:  There is unfavorable response to prolonged anti-malarial drug therapy
3023.answer_content: There is lymphocytic infiltration of hepatic sinusoids

3024.query:
Which of the following is NOT  associated with Enteric fever?
 A:  Severe cases should receive high dose dexamethasone
 B:  Ciprofloxacin is the treatment of choice in the UK. for adults
 C:  If perforation of the bowel occurs it should be managed conservatively because surgery carries too high a mortality
 D:  Jaundice is a recognized complication
 E:  Myocarditis is a recognized complication
3024.answer_content: If perforation of the bowel occurs it should be managed conservatively because surgery carries too high a mortality

3025.query:
Which of the following statements is True about Enteric fever?
 A:  The incubation period is usually 4-6 weeks
 B:  Gallstones increase the risk of chronic fecal carriage
 C:  Rose spots occur in typhoid but not paratyphoid fever
 D:  Bone marrow culture increases diagnostic yield in those previously given antibiotics
 E:  Leukocytosis supports the diagnosis of typhoid
3025.answer_content: Bone marrow culture increases diagnostic yield in those previously given antibiotics

3026.query:
Which of these is the best treatment option for recurrent inguinal hernia after open repair?
 A:  Inguinal mesh hernioplasty
 B:  Laparascopic hernia repair
 C:  Bassinni repair
 D:  Shouldice repair
 E:  McVay repair

3027.query:
Among groin hernias, which of these is least likely to incarcerate?
 A:  Direct inguinal hernia
 B:  Indirect inguinal hernia
 C:  Pantaloon hernia
 D:  Sliding hernia
 E:  Scrotal hernia

3028.query:
The most important aetiological factor in incisional hernias is
 A:  Obesity
 B:  Wound infection
 C:  Malnutrition
 D:  Choice of sutures
 E:  Increased intra- abdominal pressure

3029.query:
Which of the following statements is correct concerning hernias?
 A:  A femoral hernia is the most common hernia in females
 B:  Direct inguinal hernias pass through internal ring
 C:  Littre’s hernia contains omentum
 D:  Inguinal hernias in children are treated by herniorrhaphy
 E:  Testicular atrophy may occur after inguinal hernia repair
3029.answer_content: Testicular atrophy may occur after inguinal hernia repair

3030.query:
The most common anorectal fistula is
 A:  Intersphincteric
 B:  Transphincteric
 C:  Suprasphincteric
 D:  Extrasphincteric
 E:  Miscellaneous/Nonclassified

3031.query:
Which of the following statements is NOT True about haemorrhoids?
 A:  Haemorrhoids are specialized cushions present in everyone that aid continence
 B:  Pain is often associated with uncomplicated haemorrhoids
 C:  External haemorrhoids are covered by skin whereas internal haemorrhoids are covered by mucosa
 D:  Proctoscopy may be necessary in evaluation of haemorrhoids
 E:  Haemorrhoidectomy is reserved for third- and fourth-degree haemorrhoids
3031.answer_content: Pain is often associated with uncomplicated haemorrhoids

3032.query:
A 50 year old man presented with rectal bleeding and constipation. He has a malignant rectal mass 13 cm from the anal verge. Which of these is the correct treatment?
 A:  Colostomy
 B:  Excisional biopsy
 C:  Anterior resection of rectum
 D:  Antero-lateral resection of the rectum
 E:  Abdomino- perineal resection of the rectum

3033.query:
Which of the following is NOT a clinical feature of Carcinoma of the stomach?
 A:  Troissiers sign
 B:  Hepatomegaly
 C:  Dyspepsia
 D:  Haematemesis
 E:  Rosenbach’s sign

3034.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning carcinoma of the stomach?
 A:  65% are found in the pyloric antrum
 B:  50% are found in the body
 C:  30% are found in the fundus
 D:  It does not spread directly
 E:  Transcoelomic spread does not occur
3034.answer_content: 65% are found in the pyloric antrum

3035.query:
Chronic perianal disease is NOT a complication of which of the following?
 A:  Colonic diverticular disease
 B:  Gastrointestinal tuberculosis
 C:  Polyposis coli
 D:  Carcinoma of recto-sigmoid
 E:  Crohn’s disease

3036.query:
Which of the following is NOT a sign of strangulated intestinal obstruction?
 A:  Abdominal distension
 B:  Rebound tenderness
 C:  Increased bowel sounds
 D:  Leukocytosis
 E:  Nasogastric suction does not relief pain

3037.query:
Which of the following statements is NOT True in acute intestinal obstruction?
 A:  Signs of peritonitis indicate strangulation
 B:  Signs of dehydration are absent in late cases
 C:  A rectal examination is essential
 D:  A plain x ray examination of the abdomen is not helpful in the diagnosis
 E:  Any size of cannula can be used for fluid resuscitation
3037.answer_content: A plain x ray examination of the abdomen is not helpful in the diagnosis

3038.query:
In acute intestinal obstruction, which of the following statements is True?
 A:  Vomiting and constipation are early in high type
 B:  Low type has a better prognosis than high type
 C:  The blood supply is affected in simple obstruction
 D:  Serum potassium value of 5.5mmol/l is common
 E:  Adequate resuscitation before surgery improves outcome
3038.answer_content: Adequate resuscitation before surgery improves outcome

3039.query:
Which of the following is NOT  a cause of colonic pseudo-obstruction?
 A:  Systemic illness
 B:  Electrolyte imbalance
 C:  Faecal impaction
 D:  Opioids
 E:  Hypothyroidism

3040.query:
Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding Meckel’s diverticulum?
 A:  It is approximately 2 inches long
 B:  It is a remnant of the embryonic vitelline duct
 C:  It is usually located 2 metres from the ileo-cecal junction in the terminal ileum
 D:  It may contain gastric and pancreatic epithelial tissue
 E:  It is present in approximately 2% of the population
3040.answer_content: It is usually located 2 metres from the ileo-cecal junction in the terminal ileum

3041.query:
Which of the following statements is True regarding typhoid enteritis?
 A:  It is characterised by leucocytosis
 B:  Acute intestinal perforation is not a common complication
 C:  It can be complicated by orchitis
 D:  Perforation occurs at the mesenteric border of the intestine
 E:  Perforation occurs in less than 5% of cases
3041.answer_content: It can be complicated by orchitis

3042.query:
Which of the following is NOT a differential diagnosis for right iliac fossa pain?
 A:  Tubo-ovarian mass
 B:  Acute pyelonephritis
 C:  Chron’s disease
 D:  Empyema of gall bladder
 E:  Splenic vein thrombosis

3043.query:
What is the most common post-operative complication after splenectomy?
 A:  Left lower lobe atelectasis
 B:  Persistent hemorrhage
 C:  Subphrenic abscess
 D:  Gastrocutaneous fistula
 E:  Pancreatitis

3044.query:
In Acute Peritonitis, in which of these conditions is operative treatment usually urgent?
 A:  Amebic colitis
 B:  Acute diverticulitis
 C:  Acute cholecystitis
 D:  Perforation of hollow viscus
 E:  Primary peritonitis

3045.query:
Concerning pancreatitis, which of the following statements is True?
 A:  Cholelithiasis is the commonest cause
 B:  Cullen’s sign is associated with bruising in flanks
 C:  Steroids are not associated with acute pancreatitis
 D:  The treatment of sterile necrotizing pancreatitis is always surgery
 E:  A pseudocyst should be drained within 2 weeks of the acute attack

3046.query:
In obstructive jaundice, which of the following statements is correct?
 A:  Serum alkaline phosphatase is normal
 B:  Oral cholecystogram is of value
 C:  The gallbladder is palpable
 D:  There is splenomegaly
 E:  Vitamin K absorption is impaired

3047.query:
A 47 year old lady complains of epigastric and slight hypochondrial pain. She also feels nauseated and has been vomiting for the past 24 hours. She recalls that her symptoms started when she was eating fried plantain. The pain did not respond to over-the-counter antacids. On examination she is an obese lady. Which of the following is the most appropriate next investigation?
 A:  Erect abdominal X-ray
 B:  Upper gastro-intestinal (GI) endoscopy
 C:  Ultrasound scan of the abdomen
 D:  HI breath test for H. Pylori
 E:  Computerized tomographic (CT) scan abdomen

3048.query:
Differential diagnosis of chronic duodenal ulcer does NOT include
 A:  Reflux oesophagitis
 B:  Chronic pancreatitis
 C:  Carcinoma of the transverse colon
 D:  Liver cirrhosis
 E:  Carcinoma of the rectum

3049.query:
A 45 year old man complains of acute epigastric pain radiating to his back, and he has vomited repeatedly. On examination his temperature is 38.3 0 C, abdomen is tender, and serum amylase is 1856 U/L . What is the most likely diagnosis?
 A:  Gastric Ulcer
 B:  Acute cholecystitis
 C:  Acute pancreatitis
 D:  Pancreatic cancer
 E:  Cholangitis

3050.query:
What is the cause of hypotension in abdominal compartment syndrome?
 A:  Decreased cerebral perfusion
 B:  Decreased respirations
 C:  Cardiac tamponade
 D:  Decreased venous return from the lower extremities
 E:  Renal insufficiency
3050.answer_content: Decreased venous return from the lower extremities

3051.query:
Preferred incision for abdominal exploration in blunt injury to the abdomen is
 A:  Depends on the organ to explore
 B:  Always midline incision
 C:  Paramedian incision
 D:  Lanz incision
 E:  Right subcostal incision

3052.query:
A 24 year old patient with penetrating abdominal injury (Blood Pressure of 84/60 mmHg, pulse of 116 bpm) was brought to Accident and Emergency unit. What is the next best step in management?
 A:  Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST)
 B:  Ultrasound of the abdomen
 C:  Computerized tomography (CT) of the abdomen with contrast
 D:  Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the abdomen
 E:  Take to the operating theatre

3053.query:
The primary method of imaging of the stable blunt abdominal trauma patient, supporting the evolution of non-operative management in many solid abdominal organ injuries is
 A:  Plain radiograph of the abdomen
 B:  Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST)
 C:  Abdominal Computerized tomography (CT) with intravenous (IV) contrast
 D:  Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the abdomen
 E:  Diagnostic peritoneal lavage
3053.answer_content: Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (FAST)

3054.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning carcinoma of the breast?
 A:  T1 breast lesion is 2-5 cm in dimension
 B:  Breast cancer metastasis to bone is relatively uncommon
 C:  Tamoxifen should be prescribed for life to patients with breast cancer
 D:  Axillary lymph node involvement is a good predictor of outcome
 E:  Comedo DCIS is associated with low recurrence rate
3054.answer_content: Comedo DCIS is associated with low recurrence rate

3055.query:
What is the most common histological type of breast cancer seen in this environment?
 A:  Sarcoma of the breast
 B:  Invasive lobular carcinoma
 C:  Medullary carcinoma
 D:  Invasive ductal carcinoma
 E:  Squamous cell carcinoma

3056.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning Hypoparathyroidism?
 A:  May present with anorexia, nausea, and vomiting
 B:  There is tingling of fingers and facial muscles with low serum calcium and normal alkaline phosphate
 C:  May cause nephrocalcinosis and renal insufficiency
 D:  Low serum alkaline phosphatase and low serum phosphate
 E:  High dose cortisone and Mithramycin are used for treatment
3056.answer_content: There is tingling of fingers and facial muscles with low serum calcium and normal alkaline phosphate

3057.query:
Which of the following statements is True concerning treatment of simple nodular Goitre?
 A:  Males are more affected than females
 B:  Radioactive iodine can be used
 C:  Antithyroid drugs are used
 D:  Subtotal thyroidectomy is the best option
 E:  Surgery can be complicated by hyperthyroidism
3057.answer_content: Subtotal thyroidectomy is the best option

3058.query:
Which of the following statements is true concerning Pretibial myxoedema?
 A:  Occurs in about 20% of patients with Grave’s disease
 B:  Is a painless thickening of the skin with nodules or plaques
 C:  Usually occurs on the sole of the foot and back of the leg
 D:  Is not associated with ophthalmopathy
 E:  Resembles finger clubbing
3058.answer_content: Is a painless thickening of the skin with nodules or plaques

3059.query:
Secondary causes of Diabetes Mellitus include the following except
 A:  Acromegaly
 B:  Cushing syndrome
 C:  Chronic Pancreatitis
 D:  Insulinoma
 E:  n/a

3060.query:
Which of these statements is NOT true about Pulmonary atelectasis?
 A:  Impairs gas exchange
 B:  May predispose to chest infection
 C:  Is a common cause of post-operative fever
 D:  May necessitate fibreoptic bronchoscopy to extract mucus plug
 E:  Can be prevented by prophylactic treatment with antibiotics
3060.answer_content: Can be prevented by prophylactic treatment with antibiotics

3061.query:
Which of the following is NOT True about recent developments in endoscopy?
 A:  Chromoendoscopy involves the use of stains or pigments to improve tissue localization
 B:  Narrow-band imaging relies on an optical filter technology that radically improves the visibility of veins and capillaries
 C:  Balloon enteroscopy permits visualization of the small bowel but is unable to perform therapeutic procedures
 D:  High-resolution magnifying endoscopy achieves near cellular definition of the mucosa
 E:  Capsule endoscopy acquires video images during natural propulsion through the gut
3061.answer_content: Balloon enteroscopy permits visualization of the small bowel but is unable to perform therapeutic procedures

3062.query:
About the adrenal gland, the following are true except
 A:  The adrenal cortex is composed of three zones: an outer zona glomerulosa, a zona fasciculata, and an inner zona reticularis
 B:  The zona glomerulosa produces cortisol and androgens
 C:  Adrenal medulla secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine
 D:  The zona fasciculata is the thickest layer of the adrenal cortex, making up about 75% of the cortex.
 E:  n/a
3062.answer_content: The zona glomerulosa produces cortisol and androgens

3063.query:
Which of the following statements is True regarding endoscopy?
 A:  Verbal consent for an endoscopy is acceptable practice
 B:  The current state-of-the-art endoscope is the fiberoptic endoscope
 C:  It is easy to get views beyond the ligament of Treitz during an oesophago-gastro-duodenoscopy (OGD) with a standard endoscope
 D:  It is not necessary to stop Clopidogrel before a colonoscopic polypectomy
 E:  Perforation and haemorrhage are uncommon but significant complications of the procedure
3063.answer_content: Perforation and haemorrhage are uncommon but significant complications of the procedure

3064.query:
Which of the following statements is NOT True regarding preoperative management in a diabetic patient for abdominal surgery?
 A:  Normal Saline is used to hydrate patient preoperatively
 B:  Urinary catheterization is  performed preoperatively
 C:  Urinary output is monitored preoperatively
 D:  Therapeutic antibiotic is started on the day of admission
 E:  Intramuscular Vitamin K is administered to prevent clotting problems intraoperatively
3064.answer_content: Therapeutic antibiotic is started on the day of admission

3065.query:
28-year-old man presented with excessive sweating, palpitations, headaches and feeling of impending doom. Blood pressure during clinic visit is 200/130 mmHg.
The most likely diagnosis is
 A:  Pheochromocytoma
 B:  Cushing syndrome
 C:  Hypothyroidism
 D:  Addison’s disease
 E:  n/a

3066.query:
Informed consent relates to information pertaining to
 A:  Indications and time planning of surgery
 B:  Discussion with surgeon and hospital administrator

3236.query:
The following are common presenting features of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia:

The following conditions are associated with respiratory distress in the newborn:

Characteristics of bronchiolitis include:

The following are recognized causes of positive shifting dullness in childhood:

 C:  Atrial septal defect
 D:  Endomyocardial fibrosis
 E:  Uraemia

3240.query:
The components of tumor lysis syndrome include:
 A:  Hyperphosphatemia

 C:  Hyper-uricemia
 D:  Hypokalemia
 E:  Glucose intolerance

3241.query:
In the examination of the abdomen in children:
 A:  The spleen enlarges toward the left iliac fossa
 B:  Puddle sign is a useful method for detection of massive ascites

 D:  Bowel sounds are hypoactive in intussusception
 E:  Percussion note over enlarged kidneys are resonant
3241.answer_content: Percussion note over enlarged kidneys are resonant

3242.query:
The following are causes of coma in children:
 A:  Hepatic failure
 B:  Tetanus
 C:  Cerebral malaria
 D:  Meningitis

3243.query:

 B:  Carbuncles are multiple hair follicle infections
 C:  Scabetic lesions are typically non-pruritic
 D:  Potassium hydroxide is useful in the diagnosis of superficial mycosis
 E:  Macules are raised oval well-circumscribed lesion
3243.answer_content: Furuncles are deeper hair follicle infections

3244.query:
Concerning tuberculosis:
 A:  Rarely affect children who have received BCG vaccine
 B:  Pleural effusion is a prominent feature of primary disease
 C:  Phyctenular conjunctivitis is a feature
 D:  Incubation period is 10-14 days
 E:  Widened superior mediastinum is a diagnostic radiologic feature

3245.query:
A 10-year old girl presents with laboured breathing. She weighs 75 kg. Which other morbidities should be searched for?
 A:  Sleep apnea
 B:  Glucose intolerance
 C:  Hypoglycaemia
 D:  Systemic hypertension
 E:  Pseudotumour cerebri

3246.query:
A 6-year old boy presents at the CHER with three days history of fever, passage of dark coloured urine and weakness. On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 72/minute, heart rate of 156/minute, and a tender hepatomegaly of 3 cm. A side laboratory PCV is 13%. Which of these are essential management steps?
 A:  Cardiac positioning
 B:  Tredenlenburg position
 C:  Whole blood transfusion
 D:  Intravenous Frusemide 2mg/kg
 E:  Digoxin 0.02mg/kg stat

3247.query:
Common causes of neonatal anemia in Nigeria include:
 A:  Hereditary elliptocytosis
 B:  Pyruvate Kinase deficiency
 C:  Beta Thalassaemia
 D:  G6PD deficiency
 E:  Vitamin K deficiency

3248.query:
A newborn infant with an Apgar score of 3 at 1 minute and 5 at 5 minutes has just been admitted. Which of the following management steps are essential in the first 24 hours?
 A:  10% Dextrose-in-Water
 B:  Mechanical ventilation
 C:  Carbamazepine
 D:  Magnesium sulphate
 E:  Sodium bicarbonate

3249.query:
Which of the following drugs are useful for the closure of a patent ductus arteriosus?
 A:  Adenosine
 B:  Aminophylline
 C:  Acetaminophen
 D:  Indomethacin
 E:  Ibuprofen

3250.query:
The following congenital heart diseases are associated with oligaemic pulmonary circulation:
 A:  Ventricular septal defect
 B:  Tetralogy of Fallot
 C:  Truncus arteriosus
 D:  Transposition of the great arteries
 E:  Patent ductus arteriosus

3251.query:
An 8-month old infant presents with the history of excessive crying and associated passage of bloody mucoid stool. These symptoms were preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. On examination he is pale, irritable with palpable sausage shaped mass in the abdomen. The most likely diagnosis is:
 A:  Pyloric stenosis
 B:  Duodenal Atresia
 C:  Hemolytic uraemic syndrome
 D:  Intussusception
 E:  Shigellosis

3252.query:
Concerning urinary tract infections in children
 A:  Incidence is higher among adolescent males
 B:  E. coli is the commonest aetiology
 C:  Renal scarring is a complication
 D:  Micturating cystourethrogram is mandatory
 E:  Causes lower abdominal pain
3252.answer_content: E. coli is the commonest aetiology

3253.query:
Effects of prolonged steroid therapy in children include the following
 A:  Cataract
 B:  Glaucoma
 C:  Peptic ulceration
 D:  Pulmonary hypertension
 E:  Gross ascites

3254.query:
A 5 year old girl whose mother is pregnant, was brought in with vomiting and abdominal pain. The mother reportedly forgot her “antenatal drugs” on the table when going out and met an empty envelope when she returned. There was marked epigastric tenderness on abdominal examination. Which of the following are relevant?
 A:  Plain Abdominal X-ray is important
 B:  Gastric lavage is contraindicated
 C:  Deferoxamine is indicated
 D:  Gastric scarring is a common complication
 E:  Blood gas estimation is mandatory

3255.query:
Manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism at birth include the following:
 A:  Small-for-Age babies
 B:  Bradycardia
 C:  Hoarse cry
 D:  Neonatal jaundice
 E:  Spurious diarrhoea

3256.query:
Regarding cerebral palsy:
 A:  Perinatal causes are commoner than prenatal causes in Africa
 B:  Choreoathetoid is the commonest type in Africa
 C:  Predominant cause in Nigeria is congenital toxoplasmosis
 D:  Cortical atrophy is the basic pathologic manifestation
 E:  Mental retardation is a constant feature
3256.answer_content: Perinatal causes are commoner than prenatal causes in Africa

3257.query:
The following conditions predispose to foetal macrosomia:
 A:  Maternal anaemia
 B:  Gestational diabetes
 C:  Maternal malnutrition
 D:  Beckwith-Wiedermann syndrome
 E:  Maternal thyrotoxicosis

3258.query:
The following bedside urinalysis finding and the disease conditions are well matched:
 A:  Ketones - Diabetes mellitus
 B:  Nitrites – Cystitis
 C:  Urobilinogen – Hepatitis
 D:  Blood - Acute glomerulonephritis
 E:  Glucose - Renal Tubular Acidosis

3259.query:
Causes of loud stridor in childhood include the following:
 A:  Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis
 B:  Endobronchial tuberculosis
 C:  Laryngomalacia
 D:  Severe pneumonia
 E:  Foreign body in the larynx

3260.query:
Which of the following are manifestations of sickle cell vaso-occlusion:
 A:  Stroke
 B:  Priapism
 C:  Acute chest syndrome
 D:  Hyposthenuria
 E:  Papillary necrosis

3261.query:
In hyponatraemia dehydration:
 A:  Salt is taken in excess of water
 B:  Mild degree can be treated with dietary modification
 C:  A common cause of cardiac arrhythmia
 D:  Seizures may occur
 E:  The skin is typically doughy
3261.answer_content: Mild degree can be treated with dietary modification

3262.query:
A 4-day old term neonate delivered at the church presents with poor suck and respiratory difficulty. Examination reveals axillary temperature of 35.1 C and hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following are known risk factors for the likely disease?
 A:  Vitamin K deficiency
 B:  Peripartum fever in the mother
 C:  Antepartum haemorrhage
 D:  Prolonged labour
 E:  n/a

3263.query:
A 2-year old presents with occipitofrontal circumference of 55 cm, sutural diastasis and prominent scalp veins. The following factors are relevant in the aetiology of the condition:
 A:  Anencephaly
 B:  Intracranial haemorrhage
 C:  Aqueductal stenosis
 D:  Pyogenic meningitis
 E:  Cerebral malaria

3264.query:
A 3-month old child delivered at gestational age of 31 weeks and hospitalized for six weeks presents with recurrent cough of four weeks duration. Examination shows enlarged wrist joints and widely patent anterior fontanelle. The following findings will support the diagnosis:
 A:  Pectus carinatum
 B:  Large tongue
 C:  Craniotabes
 D:  Spina bifida
 E:  Craniosynostosis

3265.query:
In cerebral malaria:
 A:  The age incidence is 6-10 years
 B:  Convulsion is a constant feature
 C:  Altered sensorium is typical
 D:  Drug of choice is intravenous artesunate
 E:  Cortical blindness is a known sequela

3266.query:
Concerning childhood pneumonia:
 A:  Lobar pneumonia is commonest in infancy
 B:  Haemophilus influenzae Type b is the commonest aetiology
 C:  Pneumatocoeles characterize staphylococcal pneumonia
 D:  Giant cell disease occurs in measles
 E:  Exposure to biomass fuel is a risk factor

3267.query:
Duckett Jones minor criteria in acute rheumatic fever include:
 A:  Presence of subcutaneous nodules
 B:  Elevated Erythrocyte Sedimentation rate
 C:  Presence of cardiac murmurs
 D:  Arthralgia
 E:  Syndeham chorea

3268.query:
A 7-year old girl presents with a 4-week history of painless jaw swelling. The weight-for-height Z-score is-2 SD. She has generalized rubbery and discrete lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is correct?
 A:  Starry –Sky appearance on histology is diagnostic
 B:  Reed-Steinberg cells on histology is diagnostic
 C:  Jaw X-Ray shows loss of dental lamina dura
 D:  Generalized pruritus is a classical finding
 E:  Acute kidney injury may complicate treatment
3268.answer_content: Starry –Sky appearance on histology is diagnostic

3269.query:
Extra-cardiac feature of right ventricular endomyocardial fibrosis include:
 A:  Gross ascites and minimal pedal oedema
 B:  Subcutaneous nodules on extensor limb surfaces
 C:  Digital clubbing
 D:  Polyarthritis
 E:  Proptosis
3269.answer_content: Gross ascites and minimal pedal oedema

3270.query:
A 3-year old boy presents at the CHER with five-day history of progressive facial and leg swellings. On examination, he has moderate bilateral pitting pedal swelling, tachypnea and blood pressure 120/80 mmHg. Urinalysis shows one plus proteinuria. Which of the following statements is valid?
 A:  History of feed refusal or sore throat is helpful
 B:  Lesions of papular urticaria on the skin are useful
 C:  Urinalysis will demonstrate positive nitrites
 D:  Serum Anti-Streptolysin O titre will be elevated
 E:  Jaundice will be an unusual finding
3270.answer_content: History of feed refusal or sore throat is helpful

3271.query:
Concerning immunization:
 A:  BCG, OPV0 and Hepatitis B vaccine are administered at birth
 B:  Pentavalent vaccine is administered at 6, 10 and 14 weeks
 C:  Rotavirus vaccine is administered orally at 14 weeks, 6 months and 9 months
 D:  Pneumococcal vaccine and injectable polio vaccines are administered at 14 weeks
 E:  Booster doses of measles vaccine are recommended before 5 years of age
3271.answer_content: BCG, OPV0 and Hepatitis B vaccine are administered at birth

3272.query:
A 2-year old presents with passage of blood-streaked loose stools associated with episodic intense crying. Which of these statements about the child is correct?
 A:  Rotavirus vaccine could have prevented the illness
 B:  Stool microscopy will show cysts of Entamoeba histolytica
 C:  Stool pH will be less than 7.0
 D:  Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is a common cause
 E:  Doxycycline is a drug of choice in the treatment of the child
3272.answer_content: Stool microscopy will show cysts of Entamoeba histolytica

3273.query:
A 6-year old presents with breathlessness, wheezing and generalized rhonchi. The likely aetiologies include:
 A:  Acute laryngotracheobronchitis
 B:  Bronchiolitis
 C:  Laryngeal web
 D:  Foreign body aspiration
 E:  Endobronchial tuberculosis

3274.query:
Concerning iron deficiency anaemia:
 A:  Iron store is depleted by the age of 6 weeks
 B:  Blood film shows reduced reticulocyte count
 C:  Peripheral blood film shows normochromic microcytic cells
 D:  Poor school performance is a manifestation
 E:  Treatment is with 30mg/kg/day elemental iron
3274.answer_content: Poor school performance is a manifestation

3275.query:
A 9-month old child presents with hypertonia, hyper-reflexia, sustained ankle-clonus on the right side of the body. The likely background aetiologies include:
 A:  Sickle Cell Trait
 B:  Hypertonic dehydration
 C:  Pyogenic meningitis
 D:  Severe perinatal asphyxia
 E:  Kernicterus

3276.query:
The following are colposcopic features suggestive of early invasion
 A:  acetowhite epithelium
 B:  surface contour changes
 C:  mosaicism
 D:  atypical vessels
 E:  leucoplakia

3277.query:
Concerning labour
 A:  Food is contraindicated in labour
 B:  Ideal fluid for induction of labour is Dextrose in water for energy
 C:  Meconium stained liquor is synonymous with fetal distress
 D:  Fetal heart rate monitoring is every 30 minutes for high risk patient
 E:  Beat to beat variability in CTG of 5-25 is adequate
3277.answer_content: Beat to beat variability in CTG of 5-25 is adequate

3278.query:
Hyperemesis gravidarum
 A:  Hospital admission is mandatory
 B:  Associated with electrolyte derangement
 C:  Metabolic alkalosis is a common feature
 D:  Associated with about 3kg weight loss
 E:  Ondansetron is a useful medication for treatment

3279.query:
In the management of gestational diabetes
 A:  Insulin is commenced from the first trimester
 B:  Glyburide is as effective as Metformin throughout the semesters
 C:  Dietary control is the first line of management
 D:  Biguanides are not safe in pregnancy
 E:  HBAIc can only be used to know the previous glycaemic levels and not for diagnosis
3279.answer_content: Dietary control is the first line of management

3280.query:
The Following are causes of Chronic Pelvic Pain except
 A:  Fibroid
 B:  Endometriosis
 C:  Pelvic adhesions
 D:  Past history of rape
 E:  Fixed retroverted uterus.

3281.query:
Which of the following statements is true?
 A:  Post coital lacerations usually involve anterior cervix
 B:  Cervical ectropion can be the effect of POP
 C:  Cervical dysplasia is usually seen in transformation zone
 D:  Colposcopic directed biopsy is curative for early dysplasia
 E:  Excisional therapy is more psychological gratifying than ablative therapy
3281.answer_content: Cervical dysplasia is usually seen in transformation zone

3282.query:
Concerning shoulder dystocia
 A:  previous shoulder dystocia is a predictor
 B:  the incidence increases with prolonged second stage
 C:  ultrasonography gives an accurate fetal weight estimation
 D:  the McRoberts position should be adopted
 E:  suprapubic pressure is used in management
3282.answer_content: previous shoulder dystocia is a predictor

3283.query:
Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in the presence of:
 A:  transverse lie of the second twin
 B:  central placenta with a dead fetus at 28weeks
 C:  previous caesarean section for cephalopelvic disproportion
 D:  cord prolapse in the second stage of labour
 E:  none of the above

3284.query:
The vacuum extractor
 A:  should be used for instrumental delivery if the fetal head position cannot be identified
 B:  is available with a cup of one size only
 C:  used with the silastic cup for occipitoposterior position is associated with a higher failure rate compared with the rigid metal cup
 D:  should be used with a vacuum of about 0.8kg/cm2
 E:  is associated with more maternal trauma than the obstetric forceps
3284.answer_content: used with the silastic cup for occipitoposterior position is associated with a higher failure rate compared with the rigid metal cup

3285.query:
Amniotic Fluid
 A:  Amniotic Fluid at 10wks is about 30mls
 B:  Early amniocentesis is associated with limb deformities
 C:  Lilly curve is based on amniocentesis
 D:  Drew Smythe catheter for forewater amniotomy
 E:  500ml of fluid at 20wks is polyhydramnios

3286.query:
The epithelial tumour is:
 A:  Leydigs  tumour.
 B:  Theca cell tumour.
 C:  Teratoma.
 D:  Brenner cell tumour.
 E:  Androblastoma.

3287.query:
Regarding carcinoma of the ovary:
 A:  It is most common in developing countries.
 B:  The incidence is similar to carcinoma of the endometrium with similar prognosis.
 C:  The peak age is 80–90 years old.
 D:  The majority are epithelial in origin.
 E:  The mainstay of treatment is surgery and radiotherapy combined.
3287.answer_content: The majority are epithelial in origin.

3288.query:
The ovarian tumour associated with a raised alpha-fetoprotein (AFP):
 A:  Endodermal yolk sac tumours.
 B:  Granulosa cell tumours.
 C:  Epithelial ovarian cancer.
 D:  Dysgerminomas.
 E:  Choriocarcinoma.

3289.query:
Which of the statements describe sex cord tumours:
 A:  All granulosa cell tumours are malignant, but are usually confined to the ovary and have a good prognosis.
 B:  Call–Exner bodies are pathognomonic of theca cell tumours.
 C:  Many theca cell tumours cause post-menopausal bleeding and endometrial carcinoma.
 D:  Meigs’ syndrome is the combination of fibroma, ascites and pleural effusions.
 E:  Virilization is seen in 75 per cent of Sertoli–Leydig cell tumours.
3289.answer_content: Call–Exner bodies are pathognomonic of theca cell tumours.

3290.query:
Which of the following statements about dermoid cysts is a fallacy:
 A:  The malignancy rate is low (around 2 per cent).
 B:  Over 70 per cent are unilateral.
 C:  They are often lined by embryonic mesodermal structures.
 D:  Struma ovarii are predominantly made of thyroid tissue.
 E:  Complications include torsion, chemical peritonitis and rupture.
3290.answer_content: The malignancy rate is low (around 2 per cent).

3291.query:
With regard to the investigation of the infertile couple, which of the following statement is true?
 A:  A full hormone profile, tubal patency testing and semen analysis should be completed on all couples attending a referral for primary infertility.
 B:  A mid-luteal progesterone 0.25 nmol/L confirms ovulation.
 C:  A semen analysis should be performed prior to laparoscopy and dye to test for tubal patency.
 D:  Hysterosalpingogram, and laparoscopy and dye insufflation will gain similar information and either can be used to assess tubal patency in all patients.
 E:  A single semen analysis with a volume of 1 mL, a concentration of 10 million/mL and 30 per cent reduced motility confirms oligozoospermia, and serum testosterone, gonadotrophins and prolactin analysis should be performed.
3291.answer_content: A semen analysis should be performed prior to laparoscopy and dye to test for tubal patency.

3292.query:
The following are correct regarding thalassaemias except:
 A:  They represent the most common genetic blood disorders.
 B:  They result from an amino acid substitution.
 C:  Alpha-thalassaemia major is incompatible with intrauterine life.
 D:  It is important to screen the partner.
 E:  Beta-thalassaemia minor is not a problem antenatally
3292.answer_content: They represent the most common genetic blood disorders.

3293.query:
Which of these does not represent the lower genital tract?
 A:  The lower genital tract is lined by stratified squamous epithelium throughout life.
 B:  Vaginal pH is decreased under the influence of oestrogen.
 C:  The pH after the menopause is around 7.0.
 D:  Candida infection is increased in pregnancy, with combined oral contraceptive pill usage and broad-spectrum antibiotic usage.
 E:  Candida is the most common cause of abnormal vaginal discharge in women of childbearing age.
3293.answer_content: Vaginal pH is decreased under the influence of oestrogen.

3294.query:
Which of the following is correct regarding hyperthyroidism in pregnancy?
 A:  Should be treated surgically rather than with carbimazole.
 B:  Can be diagnosed by total T4 measurements.
 C:  More than half are due to Grave’s disease.
 D:  The main complications for the fetus include growth restriction and fetal bradycardia.
 E:  Therapy should maintain free T4 and T3 levels in the low normal range.
3294.answer_content: Therapy should maintain free T4 and T3 levels in the low normal range.

3295.query:
You review a thirty-three-year-old woman with a history of congenital heart disease in the antenatal clinic. In making a plan for the management of her pregnancy, which step is least appropriate?
 A:  Booking a detailed fetal cardiology scan.
 B:  Avoiding anaemia and prescribing supplementary iron if necessary.
 C:  Prophylactic antibiotics should operative delivery be required.
 D:  A birth pool to provide helpful extra analgesia.
 E:  May benefit from a shortened second stage of labour.
3295.answer_content: Avoiding anaemia and prescribing supplementary iron if necessary.

3296.query:
On routine antenatal blood test, a thirty-year-old woman is found to be Rhesus negative. Which piece of advice regarding the management of her pregnancy is correct?
 A:  Her fetus will also be Rhesus negative.
 B:  If there is concern later in pregnancy regarding vaginal bleeding then a Kleihauer test should be performed.
 C:  She should have a routine dose of anti-D at 23/40.
 D:  Once she has had two doses of anti-D, further administration will not be required.
 E:  If this pregnancy is not affected by Rhesus disease, there should be no problem in subsequent pregnancies.
3296.answer_content: If there is concern later in pregnancy regarding vaginal bleeding then a Kleihauer test should be performed.

3297.query:
A twenty-four-year-old I. V drug user who smokes attends the antenatal clinic. She has continued to use heroin throughout her pregnancy, but has reduced her smoking. Which complication is she most likely to experience?
 A:  Placental abruption.
 B:  Cervical incompetence.
 C:  Neonatal withdrawal syndrome.
 D:  Antepartum haemorrhage.
 E:  Severe intrauterine growth restriction.

3298.query:
Choose the best statement in regard to genetic counselling:
 A:  If no genetic basis is known for a condition, there is little use in genetic counselling for the parents.
 B:  Less anxiety is caused by performing a test as soon as possible and discussing the condition suspected with results available.
 C:  A discussion regarding termination should not be raised with the parents unless a test result has shown a serious condition.
 D:  A 1 per cent risk of miscarriage from an invasive test will be considered acceptable to all parents.
 E:  A consent form should be signed prior to genetic tests being carried out.
3298.answer_content: A consent form should be signed prior to genetic tests being carried out.

3299.query:
The obstetric doctor on call is asked to review a cardiotocograph performed prior to induction of labour in a 39/40 multigravida. Which of the following features should help to reassure the doctor that this is a normal trace?
 A:  The baseline heart rate is 100 beats per minute.
 B:  The baseline variability is <5 beats per minute.
 C:  An acceleration of 15 beats per minute for 15 seconds is present on the trace.
 D:  There are no significant accelerations of the fetal heart on the 30-minute recording.
 E:  The tocograph is picking up regular contractions.
3299.answer_content: An acceleration of 15 beats per minute for 15 seconds is present on the trace.

3300.query:
Which option is correct regarding diagnostic ultrasound?
 A:  It employs the use of low-intensity, high-frequency sound waves.
 B:  Between 12 and 20 weeks, the crown rump length and the femur length are the most reproducible assessment of gestational age.
 C:  It can be used to determine chorionicity accurately in twin pregnancy at the 20/40 scan.
 D:  An increase in nuchal translucency is associated with cardiac defects.
 E:  In 6 per cent of pregnancies there will be a serious structural abnormality.
3300.answer_content: It employs the use of low-intensity, high-frequency sound waves.

3301.query:
A thirty-seven-year-old woman attends a routine dating scan. She asks you in detail what information will be obtained from the scan. Which of the following will not be possible?
 A:  Accurate dating of the pregnancy.
 B:  The detection of placenta praevia.
 C:  The early detection of twin pregnancies.
 D:  The detection of a failed pregnancy.
 E:  The detection of uterine abnormalities.

3302.query:
In eclampsia:
 A:  Large doses of intravenous sedation are given
 B:  Caesarean section must be performed whether the fetus is dead or alive
 C:  Hypotensive drugs should not be used
 D:  Ergometrine should be avoided in the third stage of labour
 E:  Urinary output is increased
3302.answer_content: Ergometrine should be avoided in the third stage of labour

3303.query:
Twin pregnancy
 A:  Monozygotic twinning occurs at the rate of 4 per 1000 births
 B:  Incidence is higher with pregnancies induced with clomiphene citrate than in spontaneous conception
 C:  Zygocity can be determined by ultrasound
 D:  Perinatal mortality is 6 times higher compared with singleton pregnancies
 E:  Dichorionic twins are associated with more complications compared to the monochorionic twins
3303.answer_content: Monozygotic twinning occurs at the rate of 4 per 1000 births

3304.query:
Asherman’s syndrome
 A:  Is also known as amenorrhea traumatica
 B:  Arises from hypovolaemic shock following childbirth
 C:  Gives a funnel shaped appearance on hysterosalpingography
 D:  Is a cause of secondary amenorrhoea
 E:  Treatment is by endometrial resection
3304.answer_content: Is also known as amenorrhea traumatica

3305.query:
Ectopic pregnancy
 A:  Coexisting with intrauterine pregnancy is referred to as heterotopic pregnancy
 B:  The ampulla is the commonest site in the fallopian tube
 C:  Laparoscopy is useless in ruptured cases
 D:  Abdominal X-ray is useful in the diagnosis of advanced extrauterine pregnancy
 E:  Medical management is limited to those with gestational sac < 4 cm in diameter
3305.answer_content: Coexisting with intrauterine pregnancy is referred to as heterotopic pregnancy

3306.query:
Combined oral contraceptives
 A:  Is relatively safe to continue up to the age of 40 in a woman who smokes
 B:  Contains 0.2-0.5mg of ethinyl oestradiol
 C:  Ovulation is prevented by the progestogen
 D:  May be less effective in patients with epilepsy on medication
 E:  Can be used for menstrual regulation
3306.answer_content: May be less effective in patients with epilepsy on medication

3307.query:
Tranexenamic acid
 A:  Works by inhibiting fibrinolysis
 B:  Better at reducing blood loss than mefenamic acid
 C:  Effective in reducing Postpartum haemorrhage within 2hours of onset of bleeding
 D:  Has a role in myomectomy?
 E:  Is associated with an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis

3308.query:
Systemic lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
 A:  Pregnancy may exacerbate the symptoms
 B:  Flaring symptoms may mimic Preeclampsia
 C:  It’s a disease of women in the reproductive age group
 D:  It is associated with preterm delivery
 E:  Vaginal delivery is contraindicated

3309.query:
Magnesium sulphate and eclampsia
 A:  It prevents and aborts ongoing seizure
 B:  A loading dose of 10gms is usually given
 C:  Usually causes exaggerated deep tendon reflex
 D:  Calcium gluconate is an effective antidote to overdose
 E:  It can cause renal failure
3309.answer_content: Calcium gluconate is an effective antidote to overdose

3310.query:
Definitions of antenatal cardiotocograph
 A:  a normal baseline should be 120-160bpm
 B:  normal amplitude of baseline variability should be 5-25bpm
 C:  normally 2 or more accelerations should be present in 20 minutes.
 D:  maternally perceived fetal movements should be associated with accelerations
 E:  n/a

3311.query:
In relation to ovulation:
 A:  LH stimulates the thecal cells of the ovary to produce oestrogen.
 B:  FSH induces a rise in LH receptors.
 C:  Ovulation occurs 4 days after the LH surge.
 D:  The release of an oocyte from the follicle requires a sperm to lyse the follicle membrane, and results in ovulation.
 E:  Ovulation can be confirmed by measurement of LH on day 14.
3311.answer_content: LH stimulates the thecal cells of the ovary to produce oestrogen.

3312.query:

 A:  The follicular phase is always 14 days long to allow development of the follicle.
